item.title: Resident Evil Requiem Launch Smashes Series Steam Records
item.content:encoded:
Resident Evil Requiem has already broken Steam player count records for its entire franchise, despite only being a few hours old at time of writing.

A quick look at the franchise's SteamDB figures shows that Resident Evil Requiem has already achieved a peak player count of 319,392, and since we haven't technically reached the weekend yet, I wouldn't be surprised if that number grows between now and Sunday evening.

Requiem's peak Steam player count easily dwarfs the series' next most popular installment, namely the Resident Evil 4 remake, which achieved a peak player count of 168,191 upon its release. Requiem hasn't doubled that quite yet, but I'd be surprised if it didn't cross that line.

Just in case you're curious, the next most popular Resident Evil installments (according to SteamDB) are Village, Resident Evil 2, and Resident Evil 3, and the latter two fell short of breaking 100,000 peak players by quite some distance.

It's worth noting that this figure isn't the same as sales, although based on Requiem's staggering popularity, it's likely that Capcom is about to announce a pretty impressive sales figure for the game in its first few days.

If you're not familiar with Resident Evil Requiem, it's the latest mainline installment in the popular Resident Evil series of survival horror games. This one takes you back to Raccoon City, which you'll explore as both new protagonist Grace Ashcroft and returning hero Leon S. Kennedy.

As you can probably guess, Grace's gameplay segments are more geared towards the survival horror end of the Resident Evil spectrum, while Leon's tend more towards a Resident Evil 4-style action focus.

You can check out Resident Evil Requiem right now on PC, PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X|S, and Nintendo Switch 2, and if you want to find out what our very own Andrew Stretch thought of the game, you can read his review here.

item.title: Pokemon Winds and Waves Officially Revealed for 2027
item.content:encoded:
Pokemon Winds and Waves have officially been revealed by Nintendo and Game Freak, and they're landing simultaneously worldwide on Switch 2 next year (no Switch 1 release, it seems).

The games were unveiled at the very conclusion of today's Pokemon Presents showcase, and while there wasn't a tremendous amount of note elsewhere in the show, we got to see a lot more of the tenth Pokemon generation than I was expecting.

The reveal trailer kicks off with two new cosplay Pikachus wearing adorable costumes before expanding outwards to show us Pokemon's new open world, which, in accordance with the major leaks back in October, looks to take place across a series of islands.

Over the course of the introductory trailer, we got to see not only a look at the world of Pokemon Winds and Waves, but also at some of the Pokemon that will appear in it, including Wailord, Tangela, and Sandygast, to name but a few.

We also got to see the new starter lineup, and Nintendo and Game Freak are sticking with the Fire-Grass-Water trio, as you'd probably expect.

On the Grass side, this gen's starter is monobrowed bird Browt. It's joined by the fiery Pomeranian Pombon and the giggling water gecko Gecqua. I'm placing bets right now on Pombon becoming bipedal when it evolves into its final form.

The trailer concludes with a dive underwater, where we see more Pokemon swimming freely around. It looks like you'll be able to dive and explore beneath the water's surface as part of the game.

Pokemon Winds and Waves were revealed as part of the latest Pokemon Presents show, during which we also learned that Pokemon XD: Gale of Darkness is coming to Switch Online in March, and that Pokemon Champions will arrive on Switch in April.

Nintendo also showed off the Switch versions of Pokemon FireRed and LeafGreen, which are out today. Pokemon Home compatibility is coming to both games at some point in the future.

Pokemon Winds and Waves arrive exclusively for Switch 2 in 2027. Stay tuned for more.
